A. 

Natural Disasters in Bangladesh  

2. 
Bangladesh  is  a  disaster-prone  country.  The  unique  disposition  of  land,  water,  and 
people  in  relation  to  climate  has  resulted  in  an  unusual  pattern  and  frequency  of  disasters. 
Because Bangladesh is 1 of the 10 most densely populated countries in the world, major floods 
cause  damage  and  losses  on  a  massive  scale;  since  1904  floods  have  affected  cumulatively 
around  339  million  inhabitants  and  caused  more  than  $9  billion  in  damage  to  infrastructure.1 
Comparison of different hazards in Bangladesh illustrates that cyclones have the most dramatic 
consequences. Riverbank erosion is in second place, not in terms of deaths, but in terms of the 
process  of  impoverishment  and  landlessness  of  the  many  people  affected.  The  number  of 
deaths during monsoon floods, even during extraordinary floods, is comparatively small.2 While 
Bangladesh experiences normal floods almost every year, the incidence of extreme floods has 
increased  over  time.  During  the  last  two  decades,  the  country  experienced  three  major 
devastating  floods  in  1988,  1998,  and  2004  (Table  1).3  Details  on  floods  and  other  natural 
disasters in Bangladesh are given in Appendix 2.

Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 

3. 
The  2004  Floods.  In  late  June  2004,  heavy  monsoon  rains  swelled  the  waters  of  the 
Meghna  River.  In  early  July,  it  reached  its  peak  level,  as  the  Jamuna  and  Padma  rivers  burst 
their banks due to heavy rains in the north of the country. As a result, the north and west-central 
districts suffered severe floods that continued to spread, eventually impacting Dhaka and other 
central districts. Nationwide, 36 million people (about 25% of the population) across 39 districts 
were  affected  by  the  floods.  By  the  time  the  waters  began  to  recede  in  early  August, 
approximately  38%  of  Bangladesh  was  inundated,  including  800,000  hectares  of  agricultural 
land.  The  death  toll  reached  nearly  800.  Access  to  potable  water  and  sanitation  facilities  was 
diminished  during  the  emergency,  as  thousands  of  tubewells  and  latrines  were  affected.  The 
floods  also  caused  heavy  damage  to  major  infrastructure,  including  rural  and  municipal 
infrastructure,  roads  and  bridges,  railways,  embankments,  and  irrigation  systems,  as  well  as 
losses  to  agriculture  and  the  ready-made  garment  and  other  export  industries.  In  September 
2004,  a  localized  monsoon  depression  swept  across  Bangladesh,  bringing  three  times  the 
normal  rainfall  and  causing  urban  flooding  in  Dhaka  city,  and  southwest  and  central  areas  of 
Bangladesh.  
 
4. 
The  Government’s  Immediate  Response.  The  Government,  in  coordination  with 
nongovernment  organizations  (NGOs)  and  international  organizations,  responded  immediately 
to  the  flood  emergency.  On  7  July  2004,  the  Ministry  of  Food  and  Disaster  Management 
activated  emergency  response  committees  at  the  district  and  upazila  (subdistrict)  levels  and 
established an operations center in Dhaka to coordinate relief activities. About 5,500 emergency 
shelters  were  opened  to  house  about  1.7  million  homeless,  more  than  3,400  medical  teams 
were  mobilized,  and  800  temporary  health  centers  were  established.  Military  personnel  were 
deployed  to  assist  with  rescue  operations  and  the  distribution  of  food  and  relief  services.  To 
assist  the  flood-affected  households,  the  Government  started  the  Vulnerable  Group  Feeding 
Program  2  months  earlier  than  usual.  By  the  end  of  August,  the  Government  had  distributed 
48,000  tons  of  rice  through  its  Gratuitous  Relief  Program.  From  September  to  early  2005,  the 
Government  will  distribute  170,000  tons  of  rice,  together  with  the  World  Food  Programme, 
starting  in  the  six  most  impacted  districts  and  gradually  expanding  to  cover  the  rest.  The 
Government also distributed clothing and 10,800 bundles of corrugated iron sheets, along with 
cash grants totaling Tk5.4 million, to assist with housing reconstruction and related expenses.  
 
5. 
The  Government’s  Recovery  Program.  In  response  to  the  2004  floods,  the

12. 
Social  and  Poverty  Impacts.  According  to  the  2000  Household  Income  and 
Expenditure Survey in Bangladesh, 85% of Bangladesh’s poor live in rural areas where 53% of 
households are poor compared with a poverty rate of 37% for urban households. Although the 
2004 floods affected both poor and nonpoor households, the poor were generally least able to 
withstand  the  negative  impacts  of  the  disaster  on  household  income,  individual  health,  and 
personal  security.  Households  living  near  major  rivers  in  northeast  rural  Bangladesh  suffered 
from the longest, and generally the most severe flooding. Within these areas, landless laborers 
and  small  landholders  who  lost  crops  were  the  most  severely  impacted.  While  the  national 
average agricultural crop and livestock losses for the year have been moderate, relative losses 
to individual farmers were much larger. In urban areas, slum dwellers who typically live in poorly 
drained  areas  suffered  from  long  periods  of  water  logging,  which  reportedly  led  to  increased 
incidence  of  diarrhea  and  other  waterborne  diseases.  Floodwaters  also  reduced  employment 
opportunities and incomes of these households. Even with the benefits of Government, NGOs, 
and international relief programs, many rural and urban households resorted to informal sector 
loans  with  high  interest  rates  as  their  main  coping  strategy.  Although  these  loans  can  be 
instrumental in preventing serious reductions in food consumption and health status, the burden 
of debt repayment is likely to remain long after the visible effects of the flood are gone. Women, 
children, the disabled, and the elderly proved to be particularly vulnerable to the floods. Despite

Lessons  in  Disaster  Management  and  Flood  Rehabilitation.  ADB  has  provided 
postdisaster  emergency  assistance  to  Bangladesh  through  eight  loans  (Supplementary 
Appendix B) as well as reallocation of loan savings. Two projects have been postevaluated.15 A 
review  of  project  performance  audit  reports,  project  completion  reports,  and  ADB-wide 
experience16  with  rehabilitation  assistance  in  Bangladesh  indicates  the  following  lessons:  (i) 
projects  must  be  prepared  as  quickly  as  possible;  (ii)  projects  should  focus  on  restoring 
facilities; (iii) rehabilitation works, to the extent possible, should be completed within 2 years; (iv) 
implementation will place a heavy burden on executing agency (EA) staff and therefore strong 
consulting  support  and  ADB  supervision  are  needed  during  implementation;  and  (v)  efforts 
should be made to ensure that ADB’s rapid response to disasters is matched by equally quick 
action  by  the  Government.  Other  lessons  learned  from  ADB’s  earlier  emergency  projects 
include (i) beneficiary participation is important and should be increased in project preparation 
and  implementation,  especially  in  the  maintenance  of  facilities;  (ii)  environment  and  social 
aspects should be considered during project implementation, even though the need for a rapid 
response  may  not  permit  detailed  treatment  of  these  issues  prior  to  the  approval  of  the 
assistance; (iii) arrangements for disbursements, including retroactive financing and the use of 
imprest accounts, should give the EAs quick and simple access to funds; (ix) project objectives 
and  scope  need  to  be  carefully  defined;  and  (x)  criteria  for  subproject  selection  should  permit 
simple prioritization of subprojects and short implementation periods. Recent experience of loan 
portfolio management in Bangladesh shows that anticorruption measures need to be addressed 
even under emergency projects. These lessons have been considered and incorporated in the 
design of the proposed Project.

PROJECT BENEFITS, IMPACTS, AND RISKS 

A. 

Economic Benefits  

Selected  subprojects  will  be  technically  feasible,  cost-effective,  and  represent  a  least-
61. 
cost alternative with appropriate adjustment for flood-resistant designs. Based on initial damage 
assessment, and considering the project completion report and project performance audit report 
findings of past flood damage rehabilitation projects in Bangladesh, the economic internal rate 
of  return  for  subprojects  is  expected  to  substantially  exceed  12%.  Conducted  reevaluation  of 
past  flood  damage  rehabilitation  subprojects  in  Bangladesh  involving  rehabilitation  of  major 
roads found the economic internal rates of return to range from 18% to 55%.  
 
B. 

Poverty and Other Impacts 

62. 
Poverty  Impact.  Flood  disasters  affect  the  poor  disproportionately  in  terms  of  health, 
housing, employment, livelihood, and food security. A high incidence of poverty is evident in the 
project area, ranging from 30% to as high as 57%, based on poverty mapping.28 Of the 13 worst 
flood-affected  districts,  10  have  chronic  poverty  levels  above  the  national  level  (35.5%),  as 
measured by human poverty index. Chronicity of poverty, also measured by the index, in these 
districts ranges between 32.7% and 41.9%. The poorer income groups having lost assets and 
income  have  been  worst  affected  by  the  floods.  Urban  slum  dwellers  living  in  poorly  drained 
areas  suffered  from  prolonged  water  logging,  with  high  prevalence  of  waterborne  diseases. 
Basic  facilities  and  key  infrastructure  have  to  be  restored  if  the  affected  communities  are  to 
recover from the effects of the 2004 flood following the relief and rescue support provided by the 
Government,  UN  agencies,  and  many  bilateral  agencies.  The  Project  will  benefit  the  people, 
especially the poor, in the flood-affected areas by restoring rural infrastructure, and community 
infrastructure facilities. By rehabilitating vital public and community infrastructure, the Project will 
help restore essential economic and social activities disrupted by the flood. The repair of roads, 
bridges,  and  railway  tracks,  and  improvement  of  transport  infrastructure  will  restore  basic 
access and services to health and educational facilities. Time savings will facilitate business and 
nonfarm employment. The greater access to markets for cash crops, vegetables, livestock, and 
employment,  as  well  as  the  decline  in  the  price  of  agricultural  inputs  will  contribute  to  poverty 
reduction  by  accelerating  growth  in  poor  people’s  per  capita  income  and  assets.  The  flood 
control  and  irrigation  measures  will  protect  people  exposed  to  risk  of  inundation  from  future 
flooding  and  raise  agricultural  output.  Improvement  of  municipal  infrastructure  will  improve 
health  conditions  particularly  of  the  slum  dwellers  with  improved  water  supply  and  sanitation, 
and  create  greater  access  to  employment  opportunities.  A  summary  of  the  poverty  reduction 
and social strategy is in Appendix 13.

5. 
Bangladesh generally experiences four types of floods: (i) flash floods, (ii) floods caused 
by  torrential  rains,  (iii)  river  floods,  and  (iv)  floods  caused  by  storm  surges  and  tidal  flooding. 
Flash floods, which occur within a period of a few minutes to a few hours, often occur in areas at 
the  foot  of  the  northern  and  eastern  hills,  and  are  the  result  of  heavy  rainfall  occurring  in 
neighboring  upland  areas.  Rain-fed  floods  occur  where  natural  drainage  systems  have 
deteriorated or have been disturbed by human interference. When intense rainfall takes place in 
those  areas,  natural  drainage  systems  cannot  carry  the  runoff  generated  by  the  storm  and 
causes  temporary  inundation.  River  floods  result  from  the  snowmelt  in  the  Himalayas,  and 
heavy  monsoon  rainfall  over  the  Himalayas,  Assam,  Tripura  hills,  and  the  upper  Brahmaputra 
and  Ganges  floodplains  outside  Bangladesh.  When  the  water  levels  in  the  three  major  rivers 
rise simultaneously, extreme flood events occur all over Bangladesh. Storm surges cause floods 
along  the  coastal  areas.  Storm  surges  cause  high  sea  levels  because  of  low  barometric 
pressure combined with strong onshore winds. Continental shelves along the Bay of Bengal are 
shallow, and the coast in the eastern portion is conical and funnel-like in shape. 
 
6. 
In  recent  years,  urban  flooding,  or  the  inundation  of  urban  areas,  has  become  more 
prevalent,  due  to  the  practice  of  filling  up  low-lying  areas  within  cities.  The  practice  has 
destroyed  the  natural  drainage  system  in  these  areas.  As  a  result,  floods  have  affected 
metropolitan areas such as Dhaka, Chittagong, Khulna, Rajshahi, and Sylhet, as well as towns 
like Comilla, Jessore, Mymensingh, Noakhali, and Rangpur.

The culmination of the Flood Action Plan was the publication of the Bangladesh Water 
and Flood Management Strategy in September 1995. The National Water Policy was declared 
in  1999.  The  National  Water  Management  Plan  was  formulated  and approved  in  March  2004. 
Access  to  safe  drinking  water  and  sanitation  is  its  top-most  priority.  The  National  Water 
Management Plan envisages the water sector regulated under law with independent regulatory

The  Government  has  adopted  both  structural  and  nonstructural  measures  to  control 
floods  in  Bangladesh.  Among  the  structural  measures  it  has  adopted  are  the  construction  of 
embankments,  polders,  dams,  barrages,  regulators,  sluices,  channel  improvements,  and 
methods  for  river  closure.  Embankments  have  been  found  to  be  the  most  convenient  and 
economical method of controlling floods for strategic and large urban areas. On the other hand, 
the  Government's  nonstructural  measures  for  flood  management  include  the  establishment  of 
the  Flood  Forecasting  and  Warning  Center.  The  Government  decided  to  improve  the  center's 
forecasting  services  in  1991,  when  a  flood  forecast  model  was  developed.  At  present,  flood 
forecast services are provided at 50 stations. Flood monitoring is being conducted at another 30 
stations. Flood forecasts have a lead time of 24 to 48 hours, and all forecasts are given on real-
time basis. Longer lead times are, however, required to issue earlier warnings. In addition, more 
data  is  needed  from  the  upper  river  basins  in neighboring  countries, as  is  active collaboration 
with the countries in the subregion on river management issues.

Contribution of the sector or subsector to reduce poverty in Bangladesh: 
Bangladesh, one of the poorest countries of the world, had 50% of its population living below the poverty 
line  as  of  2000.  Since  1971,  the  country  has  faced  almost  200  disasters,  including  cyclones,  floods, 
droughts, and  river  erosion,  causing severe  damage  of  assets  and  lives.  The poorer  income  groups  are 
the  most  vulnerable  to  disaster  and  have  to  struggle  to  recover  the  loss  of  their  livelihood  almost  every 
year.  Floods  aggravate  poverty  by  affecting  the  most  poor  and  vulnerable  groups.  Major  floods  (1988, 
1998, 2000, and 2004) particularly affected the poorer segment of the population. The flood-induced rural-
urban  migration  in  search  of  livelihoods  has  created  pressures  on  urban  areas.  Many  towns  and  the 
capital Dhaka also face flooding during monsoons, often due to blockage of sewerage and drains. Lack of 
flood protection, damage of infrastructure and transport facilities, combined with inadequate drainage lead 
to  water  clogging  and  overflowing  of  cropland,  water  bodies,  damage  of  housing,  etc.,  leading  to 
widespread suffering of the poor and making living conditions deplorable. In the recent flood of 2004, more 
than 33 million people were affected causing huge income losses. The Government’s Poverty Reduction 
Strategy  Paper  emphasizes  infrastructure  development  for  economic  growth  and  poverty  reduction,  as 
well as social protection for the poor. During floods, transport between villages and markets and towns is 
adversely  affected  as  road  and  associated  infrastructure  are  submerged.  Economic  activities  are 
hampered leading to large-scale unemployment, particularly for the poor in the nonformal sector. Damage 
of water and sanitation infrastructure leads to diseases and hazards.  
 
In Bangladesh, investment in transport and flood control infrastructure is critical in the overall process of 
sustainable poverty reduction. Infrastructure development projects have been highly effective in reducing 
poverty by directly or indirectly generating income. Roads and markets can influence poverty reduction by 
creating  new  employment  opportunities,  especially  in  the  nonfarm  sectors,  as  well  as  by  changing  input 
and output prices. Transport infrastructure helps the poor by providing connectivity and access to markets, 
schools, and health centers. Flood control structures are essential to protect people and assets, promote 
economic growth, and give shelter to the poor during disasters.

What type of poverty analysis is needed?  
Flood disasters affect the poor disproportionately in terms of health, housing, employment, livelihood, and 
food  security.  A  high  incidence  of  poverty  is  evident  in  the  project  area ranging  from  30%  to  as high  as 
57%, based on poverty mapping.1 Of the 13 worst flood-affected districts, 10 have chronic poverty levels 
above the national level (35.5%), as measured by human poverty index. Chronicity of poverty, according 
to the index, in these districts ranges between 32.7% and 41.9%. The poorer income groups having lost 
assets and income have been worst affected by the floods. Damage caused by 2004 flood was assessed 
through  a  participatory  process  during  the  joint  World  Bank-ADB  Damage  and  Needs  Assessment 
Mission.  The  poverty  analysis  and  loss  estimates  are  based  on  the  assessments  and  estimates  of  the 
Government,  United  Nations’  agencies,  nongovernment  organizations  (NGOs),  and  other  civil  society 
groups. During the flood, more than 68 thousand square kilometers were inundated in 39 districts affecting 
more than 2 million households. The damage included roads, bridges, embankments, railways, water and 
sanitation  infrastructure.  About  1.7  million  people  took  refuge  in  flood  shelters,  mosques,  schools,  and 
other public buildings, highways, and embankments. About 200,000 tubewells in rural areas were affected 
and  required  disinfection  and  repair.  Crop  was  damaged  in  about  2  million  acres  of  land,  3.7  million 
farmers  were  affected  causing  potential  employment  loss  for  60  million  person-days.  The  livestock  and 
poultry  subsector  suffered  an  estimated  loss  of  2  million  person-days  of  employment,  especially  for  the 
poor  and  women.  About  380,000  microfinance  beneficiaries,  who  are  all  among  the  poor  and  mostly 
women,  representing  almost  an  equal  number  of  families  have  suffered  loss  of  their  self-employment 
activities  and  livelihood.  In  the  manufacturing  sector,  4.6  million  person-days  of  employment  have  been 
lost  in  the  industrial  estates  alone and  in  handloom  sector 2  million  person-days.  These  losses  will  take 
time  to  recover  and  the  poor  will  face  difficulties  finding  an  income-earning  opportunity,  which  may  lead 
them  to  sell  assets  and  resort  to  moneylenders.  About  66,000  ponds  were  inundated  affecting  fish 
resources and employment of the rural poor.  
 
Impact  on  human  health  was  also  tremendous  causing  mostly  waterborne  diseases,  including  around 
100,000  cases  of  waterborne  diseases,  including  diarrhea.  Loss  of  income  and  employment  will  have  a 
long-term effect on health and nutrition at the household level. Besides, disruption of regular health, EPI, 
family  planning,  and  nutrition  services,  damage  of  water  and  sanitation  infrastructure  services  will  have 
long-term  negative  effects  on  child  and  maternal  health,  population  growth,  etc.,  which  cannot  be 
quantified. Other social impacts of the flood include insecurity among those who have lost assets and had 
to  move  to  shelters,  and  increased  vulnerability  to  poverty.  Loss  of  housing  and  shelters  due  to  flood-
induced erosion may lead to rural urban migration. 
 
Food  and  shelters  were  primary  needs  of  people  during  flood.  Many  affected  people  were  given  food, 
shelter,  medicine,  clothes,  etc.  by  NGOs,  other  community  groups,  development  agencies,  and 
philanthropic groups, as well as the Government. Thus many were served by community resources. But in 
the recovery phase, the people have identified poor infrastructure facilities as the most important area for 
rehabilitation for  restoring  livelihood and  access  to  other services.  Support  to  restore  income,  water  and 
sanitation facilities, housing, agriculture, etc. have also been identified as other priority areas.

Description of the Environment 

C. 
 

1. 

Physical Resources 

 
Bangladesh’s  climate  is  tropical  and  humid,  with  mainly  four  seasons:  premonsoon 
3. 
(March to May), monsoon (June to September), post-monsoon (October to November), and dry 
(December to February). Average annual rainfall is between 2,200–2,500 millimeters (mm); the 
maximum  range  is  between  1,200  and  6,500  mm.  About  80%  of  the  rainfall  occurs  during 
monsoon. The entire country is a delta formed by the deposition of sediment carried by the three 
large river systems: Brahmaputra, Ganges, and Meghna. Most of Bangladesh is located within a 
moderate  seismic  zone.  The  Government  has  recently  recognized  the  importance  of  building 
seismic factors into their building codes as well as emergency preparations and plans.   
 

2. 

Ecological Resources 

 
4. 
Bangladesh has 230 rivers of which 57 are transboundary rivers. Only 7% of these rivers 
originate  in Bangladesh.  Annual  flow  volume  of  the  rivers  is  1,200  billion  cubic  meters;  80% of 
the water flow passes during the monsoon season. The water surface slopes of the major rivers 
are very flat. Water surface slopes of the river during the monsoon season become much flatter, 
impeding evacuation of flood flow to the sea, causing the flood to spread over the low-lying lands 
for relatively longer duration.   
 
5. 
Most  of  the  rivers  are  geologically  young  and  morphologically  very  active.  Major  rivers 
carry sediment load from the large catchments of 1.8 billion to 2.0 billion tons annually. Shifting 
of the river course, the resulting riverbank erosion, and siltation are the most common problems. 
Siltation  often  causes  closing  of  the  off-takes  of  the  distributory  channels  depriving  the 
distributaries from receiving flow from the parent channels during dry months. Riverbank erosion 
has serious socioeconomic impacts on the rural areas. The 2004 flood exacerbated the erosion.   
 
6. 
Bangladesh  harbors  a  diverse  and  extensive  fauna  and  flora.  The  World  Conservation 
Union (2000a) reported 266 species of freshwater fish and 442 marine. Most of the rehabilitation 
sites  have  natural  vegetation  including  wooded  areas,  grassland,  and  other  natural  habitats; 
natural forest is absent.   
 

3. 

Economic Development, Social and Cultural Resources 

 
Bangladesh has a very high population density of over 750 persons per square kilometer. 
7. 
The overall annual population growth rate is 1.5%, while the annual urban population growth is 
around  4.9%.  This  growth  is  achieved  by  rural-urban  migration  and  territorial  expansion  of  the 
existing urban areas. Urban population growth is not expected to fall below 4% per annum before 
2010, which will result in an increase in slums and in a shortage of urban infrastructure facilities 
such as water supply, sewage, and health.  
 
8. 
The overall economic development within the areas covered under the Project is minimal. 
Bangladesh has an extensive and diversified transport system, which includes about 220,000 km 
of roads, about 2,700 km of railroads, about 6,000 km of major waterways, two major seaports, 
and  eight  airports.  The  2004  flood  caused  localized  damage  to  transport  sector  infrastructure. 
Road transport was by far the most affected transport mode.
